docs.lead_paragraph: Abortions have declined in states where new laws make it harder to have them — but they've also waned in states where abortion rights are protected, an Associated Press survey finds. Nearly everywhere, in red states and blue, abortions are down since 2010.

headline.main: AP Exclusive: Abortions Declining in Nearly All States
headline.print_headline: AP Exclusive: Abortions Declining in Nearly All States

docs.snippet: Abortions have declined in states where new laws make it harder to have them — but they've also waned in states where abortion rights are protected, an Associated Press survey finds. Nearly everywhere, in red states and blue, abortions are down...

docs.lead_paragraph: The bride is a vice president at a communications firm, and the groom is a manager at Mount Sinai Health System.
docs.snippet: The bride is a vice president at a communications firm, and the groom is a manager at Mount Sinai Health System.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Republican states, there is much less therapy than there is in Democratic ones, and people are suffering.
docs.abstract: Seth Stephens-Davidowitz Op-Ed article details how Google search data shows that little-known difference between Republican-leaning states and Democratic-leaning states is that the latter are far more likely to use therapy to treat mental illness; suggests that there may be more of a stigma surrounding mental illness in red states.
docs.snippet: In Republican states, there is much less therapy than there is in Democratic ones, and people are suffering.

docs.lead_paragraph: Those who can afford to are drilling deeper, hoping to tap new aquifers, but those new wells threaten to arouse long-dormant water disputes in the state.

headline.main: California Farmers Dig Deeper for Water, Sipping Their Neighbors Dry

docs.abstract: Farmers in California's Central Valley, desperate for new water sources amid drought, are drilling their own wells and delving deeper than ever before in search of aquifers; trend is causing alarm because it reduces underground water levels in general vicinity, essentially allowing some farmers to steal water from underneath others; dispute is playing out in murky legal territory, with new rules unlikely to take effect for years (Series: The Parched West).
docs.snippet: Those who can afford to are drilling deeper, hoping to tap new aquifers, but those new wells threaten to arouse long-dormant water disputes in the state.

docs.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is spreading a peculiarly American vision of the future. How will the rest of the world respond?

headline.main: Welcome to the Age of Digital Imperialism

docs.abstract: Bill Wasik introduces Tech and Design issue focused on examining influence of American technologies on other cultures and their values, and how foreign cultures respond.
docs.snippet: Silicon Valley is spreading a peculiarly American vision of the future. How will the rest of the world respond?

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Cooper was a former Democratic political operative who pressed civil rights groups to confront H.I.V.’s effect.

headline.main: Mario Cooper, Nexus Between AIDS Activists and Black Leaders, Dies at 61
headline.print_headline: Mario Cooper, 61, Activist Driven by Toll of AIDS on Blacks

docs.abstract: Mario Cooper, onetime Democratic political operative who called attention to disproportionate effect of AIDS on minorities, dies at age 61.
docs.snippet: Mr. Cooper was a former Democratic political operative who pressed civil rights groups to confront H.I.V.’s effect.

docs.lead_paragraph: An immense hack of millions of government personnel files is being treated as the work of foreign spies who could use the information to fake their way into more-secure computers and plunder U.S. secrets.

headline.main: After Hacking, Government Workers Warned of Potential Fraud
headline.print_headline: After Hacking, Government Workers Warned of Potential Fraud

docs.lead_paragraph: New York’s new medical marijuana program has drawn the interest of several hospitals, which have formed alliances with growers to try to make the drug accessible to their patients.

headline.main: Hospitals Back Providers Applying for New York State Marijuana Licenses

docs.abstract: North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System hospital group announces it has applied for license to distributed medical marijuana in New York, in partnership with Colorado-based medical marijuana company Silverpeak Apothecary.
docs.snippet: New York’s new medical marijuana program has drawn the interest of several hospitals, which have formed alliances with growers to try to make the drug accessible to their patients.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the third time that legislators had considered and spurned some version of health care expansion since passage of the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Health Care Expansion Is Rejected in Florida
headline.print_headline: Health Care Expansion Is Rejected in Florida

docs.abstract: Republican-led House in Florida votes 72-to-41 to defeat bill to expand health coverage to as many as 650,000 uninsured residents; it marks third time Florida lawmakers have rejected health care expansion since passage of Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: It was the third time that legislators had considered and spurned some version of health care expansion since passage of the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The plans offer primarily catastrophic coverage for major injuries and premiums are low, but benefits are limited.

headline.main: Short-Term Health Insurance Attracts Many Despite Drawbacks
headline.print_headline: Short-Term Health Insurance Attracts Many Despite Drawbacks

docs.abstract: Ann Carrns Your Money Adviser column offers questions and answers about short-term health insurance; points out health experts warn consumers to be cautious about such plans.
docs.snippet: The plans offer primarily catastrophic coverage for major injuries and premiums are low, but benefits are limited.
